awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Frontiers of Materials Chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU site award to the University of Texas at Austin, located in Austin, TX, supports the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program and the Division of Chemistry. Participants engage in research projects encompassing materials chemistry. Participants are mentored in research groups that discover, design, develop and characterize new biomaterials and energy materials. This program emphasizes laboratory safety, development of scientific communication skills, and inclusivity.  Participants are exposed to career opportunities and broader applications of materials chemistry via an interdisciplinary seminar series, with speakers from industry and academia. The principles of lab safety are showcased by training participants to be Student Safety Officers, engagement in a peer-to-peer lab safety assessment program, and creation of safety videos. The overarching theme of inclusivity aims to develop a strong sense of community.

Participants' research projects include development of new biomaterials by combining self-assembly, templating and nanotechnology; design and development of energy materials such as photovoltaic, energy storing, or catalytic materials; and development of new spectroscopic and microscopy strategies for materials analysis. This program targets underrepresented minorities and rising sophomore students in chemistry and chemical engineering. By targeting early career students, this program's intensive training instills a passion for discovery that accelerates success in college and retention of students in science and engineering fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The REU Site at the University of Texas at Austin, known as Frontiers of Materials Chemistry, offered a training program for undergraduates as well as development of mentoring skills of graduate students and faculty. For the summer program located at UT-Austin, the focus was on training and professional development in the area of materials chemistry. In addition to development of advanced technical laboratory skills suitable for research in materials science, the program aimed to cultivate life-long friendships within each cohort of science-oriented REU students. The participants were mentored to undertake advanced research projects, to communicate with scientists from other disciplines and to take ownership of their projects.  An important aspect was the adoption of safe laboratory practices in a manner that was consistent with graduate-level research programs. There was a weekly seminar program to increase exposure to other research themes in materials chemistry. There was also significant attention to professional development via weekly lunch meetings which focused on other topics including networking, career preparation, communication, ethics, time management, collaborations, and safety.  All participants plus undergraduates from other research programs were housed in a single dormitory, thus encouraging students to interact and develop friendships with participants from other scientific disciplines and from other institutions.  The main objective was to introduce cutting-edge research opportunities to students with diverse backgrounds based on their academic level and their geographical area. Professors affiliated with chemistry and chemical engineering were selected to host the students. Students were trained to prepare posters and give scientific presentations.  Each student was required to give research updates at each meeting and were mentored in the art of simplifying technical concepts into broader context statements. The end-of-summer poster session included participants (faculty, staff, students) from a variety of research programs on the campus, such as a number of STEM disciplines.  The students learned the importance of communicating their work to non-specialists.  The oral symposium was broadly publicized and well attended, and questions from the audience were encouraged after each presentation.  The applause and revelry after each successful presentation was uplifting, and each student enjoyed his/her time in the spotlight.  The two end-of-summer events provided students a broad opportunity to learn about research from other areas and engage in networking with students from other programs, levels and institutions.  The program ran for four years, supporting and training over 25 freshmen.
